source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_033_chunk1
evidence_span: The structural integrity of the oxide layer was found to be excellent.

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_033_chunk1
evidence_span: The thermal conductivity remained high for oxides up to 70 μm thick.

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_033_chunk1
evidence_span: Scanning electron microscope (SEM) examinations revealed that the bulk of the oxide had a spherical, granular microstructure providing for interconnected porosity, mainly at the triple points.

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_033_chunk1
evidence_span: With the exception of the steam autoclaved specimens, a thin inner layer was detected close to the metal substrate; this inner layer had a microstructure which was difficult to resolve with the SEM.

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_033_chunk1
evidence_span: The in-reactor corrosion enhancement was greater for oxides which had a more pronounced granular appearance at the metal-oxide interface.

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_033_chunk1
evidence_span: Post-irradiation corrosion testing in autoclaves indicated a pronounced memory effect only for those specimens which previously had a high in-reactor enhancement.

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_033_chunk1
evidence_span: The analyses of potential impurities in the oxide gave no indication of a significant enrichment of any chemical species from the primary coolant water.

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_033_chunk1
evidence_span: In high-purity water, containing no additives, where oxygen and oxidizing radicals are formed due to radiolysis, corrosion was found to be enhanced by a factor of 10 or more

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_033_chunk1
evidence_span: In pressurized-water reactors (PWR's), where the radiolytic formation of oxygen and oxidizing radicals in the coolant is suppressed by the addition of hydrogen to the coolant, the corrosion of Zircaloy was found to be less enhanced by irradiation; an increase in corrosion by a factor of 1 to 3 has been reported

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_033_chunk1
evidence_span: It was found that the waterside corrosion closely follows the ex-reactor temperature dependencies but was enhanced by a factor of between 1.2 and 3.0 when compared with the predictions of an ex-reactor corrosion model

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_033_chunk1
evidence_span: The unirradiated oxide specimens were formed under a variety of conditions: temperature 360°C to 650°C, environment (air, steam or water), and exposure times (up to 813 days).

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_033_chunk1
evidence_span: The in-reactor residence time of the fuel rods examined ranged from 300 to 1200 days

evidence_span: irradiated oxides of up to 70 μm in thickness were destructively examined

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_033_chunk4
evidence_span: The X-ray diffraction measurements on oxide films, formed in-reactor and in autoclave corrosion tests, showed that the crystal structure was mainly monoclinic with a trace of the tetragonal (high-temperature) phase.

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_033_chunk4
evidence_span: The crystal structure of the irradiated films was similar.

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_033_chunk4
evidence_span: There was some broadening of the (111)-diffraction peak for the oxides formed in-reactor; the halfwidth of the peak had doubled.

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_033_chunk4
evidence_span: This result implies that the oxide lattice had sustained some irradiation damage.

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_033_chunk4
evidence_span: The results of IMA and electron probe scans across the thickness of oxide have shown that the oxide contains the alloying elements tin, iron, and chromium in proportion to their concentration in the base metal.

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_033_chunk4
evidence_span: SIMS, which was conducted on the outer oxide surface, revealed increased iron and chromium concentrations and also small amounts of copper, possibly indicating the presence of some deposits from the reactor coolant.
